|last6= d'Arminio |first6= MA |last7= Knysz |first7= B |last8= Dietrich |first8= M |last9= Phillips |first9= A |last10= Lundgren |first10= J |display-authors= 2 | title = Decline in the AIDS and death rates in the EuroSIDA study: an observational study | journal = Lancet | volume = 362 | issue = 9377 | pages = 22–9 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12853195 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(03)13802-0}} * {{cite journal |last1 = Sterne |first1= J |last2= Hernán |first2= M |last3= Ledergerber |first3= B |last4= Tilling |first4= K |last5= Weber |first5= R |last6= Sendi |first6= P |last7= Rickenbach |first7= M |last8= Robins |first8= J |last9= Egger |first9= M |display-authors= 2 | title = Long-term effectiveness of potent antiretroviral therapy in preventing AIDS and death: a prospective cohort study | journal = Lancet | volume = 366 | issue = 9483 | pages = 378–84 | year = 2005| pmid = 16054937 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(05)67022-5}}</ref> The development of effective anti-AIDS therapies based on targeting of the HIV virus has been a major factor in convincing some denialist scientists to accept the causative role of HIV in AIDS.<ref name=jme/>
In a 2010 article on [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories]] in science, [[Ted Goertzel]] lists HIV/AIDS denialism as an example where scientific findings are being disputed on irrational grounds. He describes proponents as relying on [[rhetoric]], appeal to fairness, and the right to a dissenting opinion rather than on evidence. They frequently invoke the [[meme]] of a "courageous independent scientist resisting orthodoxy", invoking the name of persecuted physicist and astronomer [[Galileo Galilei]].<ref name = Goertzel>{{Cite journal| last1 = Goertzel | first1 = T| title = Conspiracy theories in science| journal = EMBO Reports| volume = 11| issue = 7| pages = 493–499| year = 2010| pmid = 20539311| pmc = 2897118| doi = 10.1038/embor.2010.84}}</ref> Regarding this comparison, Goertzel states: {{quote|...being a dissenter from orthodoxy is not difficult; the hard part is actually having a better theory. Publishing dissenting theories is important when they are backed by plausible evidence, but this does not mean giving critics 'equal time' to dissent from every finding by a mainstream scientist.| Goertzel, 2010<ref name = Goertzel/>}}
==Denialist community== Denialists often use their critique of the link between HIV and AIDS to promote [[alternative medicine]] as a cure, and attempt to convince HIV-infected individuals to avoid [[Antiretroviral drug|ARV therapy]] in favour of vitamins, massage, yoga and other unproven treatments.<ref name="nattrass-2007-si"/> Despite this promotion, denialists will often downplay any association with alternative therapies, and attempt to portray themselves as "dissidents". An article in the ''[[Skeptical Inquirer]]'' stated: {{quote|AIDS denialists [prefer] to characterize themselves as brave "dissidents" attempting to engage a hostile medical/industrial establishment in genuine scientific "debate." They complain that their attempts to raise questions and pose alternative hypotheses have been unjustly rejected or ignored at the cost of scientific progress itself...Given their resistance to all evidence to the contrary, today's AIDS dissidents are more aptly referred to as AIDS denialists.<ref name="nattrass-2007-si">{{cite journal | last = Nattrass | first = N | year = 2007 | title = AIDS Denialism vs. Science | volume = 31 | issue = 5 | url = http://www.csicop.org/si/show/aids_denialism_vs._science/ | journal = [[Skeptical Inquirer]]}}</ref>}}
Several scientists have been associated with HIV/AIDS denialism, although they have not themselves studied AIDS or HIV.<ref name="NewScientist"/> One of the most famous and influential is Duesberg, professor of molecular and cell biology at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], who since 1987 has disputed that the scientific evidence shows that HIV causes AIDS.<ref name=duesberg1987/> Other scientists associated with HIV/AIDS denialism include biochemists [[David Rasnick]] and [[Harvey Bialy]]. [[Kary Mullis]], who was awarded a Nobel Prize for his role in the development of the [[polymerase chain reaction]], has expressed sympathy for denialist theories.<ref name = Naked>{{cite book | title = Dancing Naked in the Mind Field | last = Mullis | first = K | year = 1998 | publisher = Vintage Books | pages = [https://books.google.com/books?id=MCAqomvRYNMC&pg=PA171#v=onepage 171–182] | isbn = 0679442553}}</ref> Biologist [[Lynn Margulis]] argued that "there's no evidence that HIV is an infectious virus" and that AIDS symptoms "overlap...completely" with those of [[syphilis]].<ref name=MargulisDiscover>{{cite news |url= http://discover.coverleaf.com/discovermagazine/201104?pg=68#pg72 |title= Lynn Margulis: Q & A |magazine= [[Discover Magazine]] |date=April 2011 |last= Teresi |first= D |pages= 66–70 |accessdate= 14 April 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110421233929/http://discover.coverleaf.com/discovermagazine/201104?pg=68 |archivedate= 21 April 2011 <!--DASHBot--> |deadurl= no}}</ref> Pathologist [[Étienne de Harven]] also expressed sympathy for HIV/AIDS denial.<ref>{{Cite book |title= HIV/AIDS in South Africa 25 years On: Psychosocial Perspectives |first1= P |last1= Rohleder |first2= L | last2= Swartz |first3= SC |last3= Kalichman |publisher= Springer |year= 2009 |isbn= 9781441903051 |page= [https://books.google.com/books?id=7r4TbLuyFZEC&pg=PA125 125]}}.</ref>{{sfn|Kalichman|2009|pages=61, 128, 180}}
Additional notable HIV/AIDS denialists include Australian academic ethicist [[Hiram Caton]], the late mathematician [[Serge Lang]],<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/25/national/25lang.html |title= Serge Lang, 78, a gadfly and mathematical theorist, dies |newspaper= The New York Times |first1= K |last1= Chang |first2= W |last2= Leary |date= 25 September 2005 |accessdate= 23 April 2010}}</ref> former college administrator [[Henry Bauer]], journalist [[Celia Farber]], American talk radio host and author on alternative and complementary medicine and nutrition [[Gary Null]], and the late activist [[Christine Maggiore]], who encouraged HIV-positive mothers to forgo anti-HIV treatment and whose 3-year-old daughter died of complications of untreated AIDS.<ref name=LATdeath>{{cite news |title= Christine Maggiore, vocal skeptic of AIDS research, dies at 52 |newspaper= Los Angeles Times |date= 30 December 2008 |accessdate= 30 December 2008 |url= http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-christine-maggiore30-2008dec30,0,7407966.story |first1=A |last1=Gorman |first2= A |last2= Zavis |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081231143934/http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-christine-maggiore30-2008dec30,0,7407966.story | archivedate= 31 December 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Nate Mendel]], bassist with the rock band [[Foo Fighters]], expressed support for HIV/AIDS denialist ideas and organized a benefit concert in January 2000 for Maggiore's organization [[Alive & Well AIDS Alternatives]].<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.motherjones.com/news/feature/2000/02/foo.html |title= Foo Fighters, HIV Deniers |magazine= [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] |date= 25 February 2000 |accessdate= 21 October 2006 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061127064425/https://www.motherjones.com/news/feature/2000/02/foo.html |archivedate= 27 November 2006 <!--DASHBot--> |deadurl= no}}</ref> Organizations of HIV/AIDS denialists include [[the Perth Group]], composed of several Australian hospital workers, and the Immunity Resource Foundation.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.immunity.org.uk/ |title= Immunity Resource Foundation (IRF) |publisher= IRF}}</ref>
HIV/AIDS denialism has received some support from [[conservatism in the United States|political conservatives]] in the United States. Duesberg's work has been published in ''[[Policy Review]]'', a journal once published by [[The Heritage Foundation]] but later acquired by the [[Hoover Institution]],{{sfn|Epstein|1996|pp=131–158}}<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.duesberg.com/about/pdpolicy.html |last1= Duesberg |first1= P |first2= BJ |last2= Ellison |title= Is the AIDS virus a science fiction |magazine=[[Policy Review]] |date=Summer 1990 |pages= 40–51}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.duesberg.com/about/pdpolicyrep.html |last1= Duesberg | first1= P |first2= BJ |last2= Ellison |title= Is HIV the cause of AIDS? |magazine= [[Policy Review]] |date=Fall 1990 |pages= 70–83}}</ref> and by [[Regnery Publishing]]. Regnery published Duesberg's ''[[Inventing the AIDS Virus]]'' in 1996,<ref name="NYRB">{{cite news |first= R |last= Horton |title= Truth and heresy about AIDS |date= 23 May 1996 |magazine= [[The New York Review of Books]] |url-access=subscription |url= http://www.nybooks.com/articles/1996/05/23/truth-and-heresy-about-aids/}}</ref> and journalist [[Tom Bethell]]'s ''[[The Politically Incorrect Guide to Science]]'', in which he endorses HIV/AIDS denialism, in 2005.<ref>{{cite book |last= Bethell |first= T |title= [[The Politically Incorrect Guide to Science]] |isbn= 089526031X |year= 2005 |publisher= Regnery Publishing |pages= [https://books.google.com/books?id=xX4m7s7_4L0C&pg=PA105 105–122]}}</ref> Law professor [[Phillip E. Johnson]] has accused the [[Centers for Disease Control]] of "fraud" in relation to HIV/AIDS.<ref name="titleHIV & AIDS – Statement About CDC Fraud">{{cite web |url= http://www.virusmyth.com/aids/hiv/pjcdc.htm |title =HIV & AIDS – Statement About CDC Fraud |accessdate= 18 March 2008 |work= virusmyth.com}}</ref> Describing the political aspects of the HIV/AIDS denialism movement, [[Sociology]] professor [[Steven Epstein (academic)|Steven Epstein]] wrote in ''Impure Science'' that "... the appeal of Duesberg's views to conservatives—certainly including those with little sympathy for the gay movement—cannot be denied."{{sfn|Epstein|1996|pp= [https://books.google.com/books?id=kZOso0FMsrMC&pg=PA131#v=onepage 131–158]}} The blog [[LewRockwell.com]] has also published articles supportive of HIV/AIDS denialism.{{sfn|Kalichman|2009|pp= [https://books.google.com/books?id=_mtDBCDwxugC&pg=PA50 50–53]}}
In a follow-up article in ''[[Skeptical Inquirer]]'',<ref name=nattrass2012>{{cite journal |last1= Nattrass |first1= N |title= The social and symbolic power of AIDS denialism |journal= Skeptical Inquirer |volume= 36 |date=July–August 2012 |pages=34–8 |publisher= [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]] |url= http://www.csicop.org/si/show/the_social_and_symbolic_power_of_aids_denialism}}</ref> Nattrass overviewed the prominent members of the HIV/AIDS denialist community and discussed the reasons of the intractable staying power of HIV/AIDS denialism in spite of scientific and medical consensus supported by over two decades of evidence. She observed that despite being a disparate group of people with very different background and professions, the HIV/AIDS denialists self-organize to fill four important roles:<ref name=nattrass2012/> * "Hero scientists" to provide scientific legitimacy: Most notably Duesberg who plays the central role of HIV/AIDS denialism from the beginning. Others include [[David Rasnick]], [[Étienne de Harven]], and [[Kary Mullis]] whose [[Nobel Prize]] makes him symbolically important. * "Cultropreneurs" to offer fake cures in place of [[Management of HIV/AIDS|antiretroviral therapy]]: [[Matthias Rath]], [[Gary Null]], Michael Ellner, and Roberto Giraldo all promote [[alternative medicine]] and remedies with a dose of conspiracy theories in the form of books, healing products, radio shows and counseling services. * HIV-positive "living icons" to provide proof of concept by appearing to live healthily without antiretroviral therapy: [[Christine Maggiore]] was and still is the most important icon in the HIV/AIDS denialist movement despite the fact that she died of AIDS related complications in 2008. * "Praise singers": sympathetic journalists and filmmakers who publicize the movement with uncritical and favorable opinion. They include journalists [[Celia Farber]], Liam Scheff and Neville Hodgkinson; filmmakers [[House of Numbers (2009 film)|Brent Leung]] and [[The Other Side of AIDS|Robert Leppo]]. Some of them had overlapping roles as board members of Rethinking AIDS and [[Alive and Well AIDS Alternatives]], were involved in the film ''[[House of Numbers (2009 film)|House of Numbers]]'', ''[[The Other Side of AIDS]]'' or on [[Thabo Mbeki]]'s AIDS Advisory Panel. Nattrass argued that HIV/AIDS denialism gains social traction through powerful community-building effects where these four organized characters form "a symbiotic connection between AIDS denialism and alternative healing modalities" and they are "facilitated by a shared conspiratorial stance toward HIV science".<ref name=nattrass2012/>
===Former denialists=== Several of the few prominent scientists who once voiced doubts about HIV/AIDS have since changed their views and accepted the fact that HIV plays a role in causing AIDS, in response to an accumulation of newer studies and data.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.aegis.com/topics/mdelaney.html |title= HIV, AIDS, and the distortion of science |first= M |last= Delaney |accessdate= 9 June 2011 |year= 2005 |magazine= [[Focus (Christian magazine)|Focus]] |volume= 15 |issue= 6 |pages= 1–6 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110604155409/http://www.aegis.com/topics/mdelaney.html |archivedate= 4 June 2011 |deadurl= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref> Root-Bernstein, author of ''Rethinking AIDS: The Tragic Cost of Premature Consensus'' and formerly a critic of the causative role of HIV in AIDS, has since distanced himself from the HIV/AIDS denialist movement, saying, "Both the camp that says HIV is a pussycat and the people who claim AIDS is all HIV are wrong...The denialists make claims that are clearly inconsistent with existing studies."<ref name=poz>{{cite news |url= http://www.poz.com/articles/451_2788.shtml |title= Dead Certain? |last= Lederer |first= B |magazine= [[POZ (magazine)|POZ]] |date= 1 April 2006 |accessdate= 31 October 2006 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061113150749/http://www.poz.com/articles/451_2788.shtml |archivedate= 13 November 2006 <!--DASHBot--> | deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[Joseph Sonnabend]], who until the late 1990s regarded the issue of AIDS causation as unresolved, has reconsidered in light of the success of newer antiretroviral drugs, stating, "The evidence now strongly supports a role for HIV… Drugs that can save your life can also under different circumstances kill you. This is a distinction that denialists do not seem to understand."<ref name=poz/> Sonnabend has also criticized HIV/AIDS denialists for falsely implying that he supports their position, saying: {{Quotation|Some individuals who believe that HIV plays no role at all in AIDS have implied that I support their misguided views on AIDS causation by including inappropriate references to me in their literature and on their web sites. Before HIV was discovered and its association with AIDS established, I held the entirely appropriate view that the cause of AIDS was then unknown. I have successfully treated hundreds of AIDS patients with antiretroviral medications, and have no doubt that HIV plays a necessary role in this disease.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.aidstruth.org/denialism/sonnabend |title= Statement by Joseph Sonnabend, M.D. |work= aidstruth.org |accessdate= 15 February 2011 |last1= Sonnabend |first1= J |deadurl= yes |archive-date= 17 May 2011 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110517101454/http://www.aidstruth.org/denialism/sonnabend |df= dmy-all }}</ref>}}
A former denialist wrote in the ''[[Journal of Medical Ethics]]'' in 2004: {{Quotation|The group [of denialists] regularly points to a substantial number of scientists supportive of its agenda to re-evaluate the HIV/AIDS hypothesis. Some of those members still listed are people who have been dead for a number of years. While it is correct that these people supported the objective of a scientific re-evaluation of the HIV/AIDS link when they were alive, it is clearly difficult to ascertain what these people would have made of the scientific developments and the accumulation of evidence for HIV as the crucial causative agent in AIDS, which has occurred in the years after their deaths.<ref name=jme>{{cite journal |last=Schüklenk |first= U |title= Professional responsibilities of biomedical scientists in public discourse |journal= J Med Ethics |volume= 30 |issue= 1 |pages=53–60; discussion 61–2 |year= 2004 |pmid= 14872076 |pmc= 1757140 |url= http://jme.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=14872076 |doi=10.1136/jme.2003.002980}}</ref>}}
=== Death of HIV-positive denialists === In 2007, aidstruth.org, a website run by HIV researchers to counter denialist claims,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Cohen |first= J |title= HIV/AIDS. AIDSTruth.org Web site takes aim at 'denialists' |journal= [[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume= 316 |issue= 5831 |page= 1554 |year= 2007 |pmid= 17569834 |doi= 10.1126/science.316.5831.1554}}</ref> published a partial list of HIV/AIDS denialists who had died of AIDS-related causes. For example, the editors of the magazine ''[[Continuum (magazine)|Continuum]]'' consistently denied the existence of HIV/AIDS. The magazine shut down after both editors died of AIDS-related causes.<ref name=NewHumanist>{{cite news |url= http://newhumanist.org.uk/2165/how-to-spot-an-aids-denialist |title= How to spot an AIDS denialist |magazine= [[New Humanist]] |date=November 2009 |last= Kalichman |first= S | authorlink = Seth Kalichman}}</ref> In each case, the HIV/AIDS denialist community attributed the deaths to unknown causes, secret drug use, or stress rather than HIV/AIDS.<ref name="denialists-who-have-died"/><ref name=jme/> Similarly, several HIV-positive former dissidents have reported being ostracized by the AIDS-denialist community after they developed AIDS and decided to pursue effective [[antiretroviral]] treatment.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.aegis.org/news/misc/2000/bg000201.html |title= Bad science: They once thought HIV was harmless. Now, they say, AIDS has forced them to reconsider |first= B |last= Mirken |newspaper= [[San Francisco Bay Guardian]] |date= 2 February 2000 |accessdate= 9 May 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080415232410/http://www.aegis.org/news/misc/2000/BG000201.html |archivedate= 15 April 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |deadurl= no}}</ref>
In 2008, activist [[Christine Maggiore]] died at the age of 52 while under a doctor's care for pneumonia. Maggiore, mother of two children, had founded [[Alive & Well AIDS Alternatives|an organisation]] to help other HIV-positive mothers avoid taking antiretroviral drugs that reduce the risk of HIV transmission from mother to child.<ref name=LATimesArticle>{{cite news |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2005/sep/24/local/me-eliza24 |title= A mother's denial, a daughter's death |newspaper= [[Los Angeles Times]] |date= 24 September 2005 |accessdate= 29 December 2008 |last1= Ornstein |first1=C |first2=D |last2= Costello | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081222041314/http://articles.latimes.com/2005/sep/24/local/me-eliza24 |archivedate= 22 December 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |deadurl= no}}</ref> After her three-year-old daughter died of [[AIDS-related pneumonia]] in 2005, Maggiore continued to believe that HIV is not the cause of AIDS, and she and her husband [[Robin Scovill]] sued [[Los Angeles County]] and others on behalf of their daughter's estate, for allegedly violating [[Eliza Scovill]]'s civil rights by releasing an autopsy report that listed her cause of death as [[AIDS-related pneumonia]].<ref name=LATdeath/> The litigants settled out of court, with the county paying Scovill $15,000 in March 2009, with no admission of wrongdoing. The L.A. coroner's ruling that Eliza Jane Scovill died of AIDS remains standing as the official verdict.<ref>{{cite news |title= Suit settled on autopsy of HIV skeptics' child |date= 6 March 2009 |first= M |last= Hennessy-Fiske |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2009/mar/06/local/me-briefs6 |newspaper= The Los Angeles Times}}</ref>
=== Local community group denialism === '''Australia:''' In 2009 representing the [[Australian Vaccination-Skeptics Network]], President [[Meryl Dorey]] signed a petition claiming that "the AIDS industry and the media" had tricked the public and the media into believing that the HIV virus causes AIDS.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Panic Virus: Fear, Myth and the Vaccination Debate|publisher = Schwartz Publishing Pty, Limited|date = 2011-01-25|isbn = 9781921870118|language = en|first = Seth|last = Mnookin|edition= Australian|page = xx}}</ref>
'''Canada:''' The Alberta Reappraising AIDS Society created the petition in March 2000 and has reportedly since attracted "2,951 doubters" representing groups and individuals through the globe. Signatories reportedly deny the theory "that Aids is heterosexually transmitted".<ref>{{Cite web|title = HIV/AIDS Rethinkers|url = http://aras.ab.ca/rethinkers.php|website = Alberta Reappraising AIDS Society|date=March 16, 2000|access-date = 2016-02-17}}</ref>
==Impact beyond the scientific community== AIDS-denialist claims have failed to attract support in the scientific community, where the evidence for the causative role of HIV in AIDS is considered conclusive. However, the movement has had a significant impact in the political sphere, culminating with former South African President [[Thabo Mbeki]]'s embrace of AIDS-denialist claims.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gray|first=A |title=''The Politics of AIDS Denialism: South Africa's Failure to Respond'' - By Pieter Fourie and Melissa Meyer|journal=Political Studies Review|volume=10|issue=2|page=309 |doi=10.1111/j.1478-9302.2012.00269_2.x |type= Book review|year=2012 }}</ref> The resulting governmental refusal to provide effective anti-HIV treatment in South Africa has been blamed for hundreds of thousands of premature AIDS-related deaths in South Africa.<ref name="nyt-dugger">{{cite news |newspaper= The New York Times |first= C |last= Dugger |date= 25 November 2008 |accessdate= 17 December 2008 |title= Study cites toll of AIDS policy in South Africa |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/26/world/africa/26aids.html}}</ref>
===North America and Europe=== Skepticism about HIV being the cause of AIDS began almost immediately after the discovery of HIV was announced. One of the earliest prominent skeptics was the journalist [[John Lauritsen]], who argued in his writings for the ''[[New York Native]]'' that AIDS was caused by [[Poppers|amyl nitrite poppers]], and that the government had conspired to hide the truth.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.virusmyth.com/aids/data2/jlbio.htm |title= Biography of John Lauritsen |work= virusmyth.com |accessdate= 7 September 2006}}</ref> Lauritsen's ''The AIDS War'' was published in 1993.<ref>{{cite book |last= Lauritsen |first= John |title= The AIDS War |publisher= Pagan Press |location= New York |year= 1993 |isbn=0-943742-08-0 |page= 4}}</ref>
====Scientific literature==== The publication of Duesberg's first AIDS paper in 1987 provided visibility for denialist claims. Shortly afterwards, the journal ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' reported that Duesberg's remarks had won him "a large amount of media attention, particularly in the gay press where he is something of a hero."<ref>{{cite journal |last=Booth |first= W |title= A rebel without a cause of AIDS |journal= Science |volume= 239 |issue= 4847 |pages= 1485–8 |year= 1988 |pmid= 3281251 |doi= 10.1126/science.3281251 |url= http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/reprint/239/4847/1485 |bibcode= 1988Sci...239.1485B}}</ref> However, Duesberg's support in the [[gay community]] diminished as he made a series of statements perceived as [[Homophobia|homophobic]]; in an interview with ''[[The Village Voice]]'' in 1988, Duesberg stated his belief that the AIDS epidemic was "caused by a lifestyle that was criminal twenty years ago."<ref name=epstein>{{cite book |last= Epstein |first= S |title= Impure Science: AIDS, Activism, and the Politics of Knowledge |publisher= University of California Press |location= Berkeley |year= 1996 |isbn=0520202333 |page= 118 |ref= {{Harvid|Epstein|1996}}}}</ref>
In the following few years, others became skeptical of the HIV theory as researchers initially failed to produce an effective treatment or vaccine for AIDS.<ref name="Burkett1995">{{cite book|last=Burkett|first=Elinor |title=The Gravest Show on Earth: America in the Age of AIDS|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YXLP4k7spJYC|year=1995|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company|isbn=978-0-395-74537-3|pages=53–76|chapter=Ch. 2: Evidence to the Contrary}}</ref> Journalists such as Neville Hodgkinson and [[Celia Farber]] regularly promoted denialist ideas in the American and British media; several television documentaries were also produced to increase awareness of the alternative viewpoint.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.virusmyth.net/aids/censorship.htm |title= Censorship |work= virusmyth.com |accessdate= 2 June 2006 |deadurl= yes |archive-date= 15 October 2009 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20091015032105/http://www.virusmyth.com/aids/censorship.htm}}</ref> In 1992–1993, ''[[The Sunday Times]]'', where Hodgkinson served as scientific editor, ran a series of articles arguing that the AIDS epidemic in Africa was a myth. These articles stressed Duesberg's claims and argued that antiviral therapy was ineffective, HIV testing unreliable, and that AIDS was not a threat to heterosexuals. The ''Sunday Times'' coverage was heavily criticized as slanted, misleading, and potentially dangerous; the scientific journal ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' took the unusual step of printing a 1993 editorial calling the paper's coverage of HIV/AIDS "seriously mistaken, and probably disastrous."<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1993/12/10/world/british-paper-and-science-journal-clash-on-aids.html |title= British paper and science journal clash on AIDS |last= Schmidt |first= WE |newspaper= The New York Times |date= 10 December 1993 |accessdate= 25 April 2008}}</ref>
Finding difficulty in publishing his arguments in the scientific literature, Duesberg exercised his right as a member of the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] to publish in ''[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America]]'' (''PNAS'') without going through the [[peer review]] process. However, Duesberg's paper raised a "red flag" at the journal and was submitted by the editor for non-binding review. All of the reviewers found major flaws in Duesberg's paper; the reviewer specifically chosen by Duesberg noted the presence of "misleading arguments", "nonlogical statements", "misrepresentations", and political overtones.<ref name=sciencebooth>{{cite journal |last=Booth |first= W |title= AIDS paper raises red flag at PNAS |journal= Science |volume= 243 |issue= 4892 |page= 733 |year=1989 |pmid=2916121|doi=10.1126/science.2916121|bibcode = 1989Sci...243..733B }}</ref> Ultimately, the editor of ''PNAS'' acquiesced to publication,<ref name=pnas1989>{{cite journal |last=Duesberg |first= PH |title=Human immunodeficiency virus and acquired immunodeficiency syndrome: Correlation but not causation |journal=[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America]] |volume= 86 |issue= 3 |pages= 755–64 |year= 1989 |pmid= 2644642 |doi= 10.1073/pnas.86.3.755 |pmc= 286556 |bibcode= 1989PNAS...86..755D}}</ref> writing to Duesberg: "If you wish to make these unsupported, vague, and prejudicial statements in print, so be it. But I cannot see how this would be convincing to any scientifically trained reader."<ref name=sciencebooth/>
HIV/AIDS denialists often resort to [[special pleading]] to support their assertion, arguing for different causes of AIDS in different locations and subpopulations. In North America, AIDS is blamed on the health effects of unprotected anal sex and poppers on homosexual men, an argument which does not account for AIDS in drug-free heterosexual women who deny participating in anal sex. In this case, HIV/AIDS denialists claim the women are having anal sex but refuse to disclose it. In [[haemophilia]]c North American children who contracted AIDS from blood transfusions, the haemophilia itself or its treatment is claimed to cause AIDS. In Africa, AIDS is blamed on poor nutrition and sanitation due to poverty. For wealthy populations in South Africa with adequate nutrition and sanitation, it is claimed that the antiretroviral drugs used to treat AIDS cause the condition. In each case, the [[Occam's razor|most parsimonious explanation]] and uniting factor – HIV positive status – is ignored, as are the thousands of studies that converge on the common conclusion that AIDS is caused by HIV infection.{{sfn|Kalichman|2009}}
Haemophilia is considered the best test of the HIV-AIDS hypothesis by both denialists and AIDS researchers. While Duesberg claims AIDS in haemophiliacs is caused by contaminated clotting factors and HIV is a harmless [[passenger virus]], this result is contradicted by large studies on haemophiliac patients who received contaminated blood. A comparison of groups receiving high, medium and low levels of contaminated clotting factors found the death rates differed significantly depending on HIV status. Of 396 HIV positive haemophiliacs followed between 1985 and 1993, 153 died. The comparative figure for the HIV negative group was one out of 66, despite comparable doses of contaminated clotting factors. A comparison of individuals receiving blood donations also supports the results; in 1994 there were 6888 individuals with AIDS who had their HIV infection traced to blood transfusions. Since the introduction of HIV testing, the number of individuals whose AIDS status can be traced to blood transfusions was only 29 (as of 1994).<ref name = CohenScience1994/>
==== Lay press and on the Internet ==== With the introduction of [[HAART|highly active antiretroviral therapy]] (HAART) in 1996–1997, the survival and general health of people with HIV improved significantly.<ref name="treatment-studies"/><ref>{{Cite journal | last2 = May | first2 = MT | last3 = Sterne | first3 = JA | last4 = Costagliola | first4 = D | last5 = Sabin | first5 = CA | last6 = Phillips | first6 = AN | last7 = Justice | first7 = AC | last8 = Dabis | first8 = F | last9 = Gill | first9 = J | last10 = Lundgren | first10 = J | last11 = Hogg | first11 = RS | last12 = De Wolf | first12 = F | last13 = Fätkenheuer | first13 = G | last14 = Staszewski | first14 = S | last15 = d'Arminio Monforte | first15 = A | last16 = Egger | first16 = M | author1 = Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) Cohort Collaboration |display-authors= 2 | title = HIV treatment response and prognosis in Europe and North America in the first decade of highly active antiretroviral therapy: A collaborative analysis | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(06)69152-6 | journal = The Lancet | volume = 368 | issue = 9534 | pages = 451–458 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16890831 | pmc = }}</ref> The positive response to treatment with anti-HIV medication cemented the scientific acceptance of the HIV/AIDS paradigm, and led several prominent HIV/AIDS denialists to accept the causative role of HIV.<ref name=jme/><ref name=poz/> Finding their arguments increasingly discredited by the scientific community, denialists took their message to the popular press. A former denialist wrote:{{Quotation|Scientists among the HIV dissidents used their academic credentials and academic affiliations to generate interest, sympathy, and allegiances in lay audiences. They were not professionally troubled about recruiting lay people—who were clearly unable to evaluate the scientific validity or otherwise of their views—to their cause.<ref name=jme/>}} In addition to elements of the popular and alternative press, AIDS denialist ideas are propagated largely via the Internet.<ref name=deer>{{cite news |last= Deer |first= B |date= 21 February 2012 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/science/blog/2012/feb/21/death-denial-hiv-aids?INTCMP=SRCH |title= Death by denial: The campaigners who continue to deny HIV causes Aids |newspaper= [[The Guardian]]}}</ref>
A 2007 article in ''[[PLoS Medicine]]'' noted: {{Quotation|Because these denialist assertions are made in books and on the Internet rather than in the scientific literature, many scientists are either unaware of the existence of organized denial groups, or believe they can safely ignore them as the discredited fringe. And indeed, most of the HIV deniers' arguments were answered long ago by scientists. However, many members of the general public do not have the scientific background to critique the assertions put forth by these groups, and not only accept them but continue to propagate them.<ref name=SmithNovella>{{cite journal |last1= Smith |first1= TC |last2= Novella |first2= SP |title= HIV denial in the internet era |journal= [[PLOS Medicine]] |volume= 4 |issue= 8 |pages= e256 |date= August 2007 |pmid= 17713982 |doi= 10.1371/journal.pmed.0040256 |url= http://medicine.plosjournals.org/perlserv/?request=get-document&doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0040256&ct=1&SESSID=3d4baa1a64e57d8ff33e9d41eb2335a1 |pmc= 1949841 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080506012410/http://medicine.plosjournals.org/perlserv/?request=get-document&doi=10.1371%2Fjournal.pmed.0040256&ct=1&SESSID=a61d4ab73afe3389776361583d621ef6 |archivedate= 6 May 2008 |deadurl= no |df= dmy-all }}</ref>}}
====Lay opinion and AIDS-related behaviors==== AIDS activists have expressed concern that denialist arguments about HIV's harmlessness may be responsible for an upsurge in HIV infections. Denialist claims continue to exert a significant influence in some communities; a survey conducted at minority gay pride events in four American cities in 2005 found that 33% of attendees doubted that HIV caused AIDS.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Hutchinson |first1= AB |last2= Begley |first2= EB |last3= Clark |first3= HA |last4= Boyett |first4= BC |last5= Jardine |first5= MA |last6= Kellerman |first6= SE |year= 2005 |url= http://www.aegis.org/conferences/nhivpc/2005/TP-011.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102062252/http://www.aegis.org/conferences/nhivpc/2005/TP-011.html|archivedate=2 January 2008|title= Mistrust and conspiracy beliefs about HIV/AIDS among participants in minority gay pride events |journal= 2005 National HIV Prevention Conference |page= Abstract TP-011 |nopp=y|display-authors= 2}}</ref> Similarly, a 2010 survey of 343 people living with HIV/AIDS found that one in five of them thought that there was no proof that HIV caused AIDS, and that HIV treatments did more harm than good.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kalichman|first1=SC|last2=Eaton|first2=L|last3=Cherry|first3=C|title='There is no proof that HIV causes AIDS': AIDS denialism beliefs among people living with HIV/AIDS|journal=[[Journal of Behavioral Medicine]]|date=December 2010|volume=33|issue=6|pages=432–40|doi=10.1007/s10865-010-9275-7|pmid=20571892|pmc=3015095}}</ref> According to Stephen Thomas, director of the [[University of Pittsburgh]] [[Center for Minority Health]], "people are focusing on the wrong thing. They're focusing on conspiracies rather than protecting themselves, rather than getting tested and seeking out appropriate care and treatment."<ref name=newsweekfrance>{{cite news |last= France |first= D |date= 28 August 2000 |title= The HIV disbelievers: Christine Maggiore is a different kind of AIDS activist-one who tells people to forget safe sex and stop taking their lifesaving drugs. Why? |magazine= [[Newsweek]] |url= http://www.newsweek.com/hiv-disbelievers-158813}}</ref> African Americans are exceptionally likely to believe that HIV does not cause AIDS, partly because they sometimes perceive the role of HIV in the disease as part of a racist agenda.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Diethelm|first1=P |last2=McKee|first2=M |title=Denialism: What is it and how should scientists respond?|journal=[[The European Journal of Public Health]]|date=16 October 2008|volume=19|issue=1|pages=2–4|doi=10.1093/eurpub/ckn139|pmid=19158101}}</ref> A 2012 survey of young adults in [[Cape Town]], South Africa found that belief in AIDS denialism was strongly related to an increased probability of engaging in [[unsafe sex]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Grebe |first=E |last2=Nattrass |first2=N |date= April 2012 |title=AIDS conspiracy beliefs and unsafe sex in Cape Town |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10461-011-9958-2 |journal=[[AIDS and Behavior]] |volume=16 |issue=3 |pages=761–73 |doi=10.1007/s10461-011-9958-2 |pmid= 21538083}}</ref>
===South Africa=== {{Main|HIV/AIDS denialism in South Africa}} HIV/AIDS denialist claims have had a major political, social, and public health impact in South Africa. The government of then President [[Thabo Mbeki]] was sympathetic to the views of HIV/AIDS denialists, with critics charging that denialist influence was responsible for the slow and ineffective governmental response to the country's massive [[AIDS epidemic]].
Independent studies have arrived at almost identical estimates of the human costs of HIV/AIDS denialism in South Africa. According to a paper written by researchers from the [[Harvard School of Public Health]], between 2000 and 2005, more than 330,000 deaths and an estimated 35,000 infant HIV infections occurred "because of a failure to accept the use of available [antiretroviral drugs] to prevent and treat HIV/AIDS in a timely manner."<ref name=chigwedere/> Nicoli Nattrass of the [[University of Cape Town]] estimates that 343,000 excess AIDS-related deaths and 171,000 infections resulted from the Mbeki administration's policies, an outcome she refers to in the words of [[Peter Mandelson]] as "genocide by sloth".<ref name=NattrassAA/>
====Durban Declaration==== In 2000, when the [[International AIDS Conference]] was held in [[Durban]], Mbeki convened a Presidential Advisory Panel containing a number of HIV/AIDS denialists, including Duesberg and [[David Rasnick]].<ref name=journaids>{{cite web |url= http://www.journaids.org/politicsofhiv.php |title= The Politics of HIV/AIDS in South Africa |accessdate= 26 February 2007 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070702083352/http://journaids.org/politicsofhiv.php |archivedate= 2 July 2007 |work= JournAIDS |publisher= HIV & AIDS Media Project}}</ref> The Advisory Panel meetings were closed to the general press; an invited reporter from the ''[[Village Voice]]'' wrote that Rasnick advocated that HIV testing be legally banned and denied that he had seen "any evidence" of an AIDS catastrophe in South Africa, while Duesberg "gave a presentation so removed from African medical reality that it left several local doctors shaking their heads."<ref name=vv/>
In his address to the International AIDS Conference, Mbeki reiterated his view that HIV was not wholly responsible for AIDS, leading hundreds of delegates to walk out on his speech.<ref name=Controversy>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/826742.stm |title= Controversy dogs AIDS forum |work= BBC News |date= 10 July 2000 |accessdate= 26 February 2007}}</ref> Mbeki also sent a letter to a number of world leaders likening the mainstream AIDS research community to supporters of the [[apartheid]] regime.<ref name=journaids/> The tone and content of Mbeki's letter led diplomats in the U.S. to initially question whether it was a hoax.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.villagevoice.com/news/0027,schoofs,16189,1.html | title=Proof positive: How African science has demonstrated that HIV causes AIDS | date=5–11 July 2000 | accessdate=20 April 2007 | last=Schoof | first=M | newspaper=[[Village Voice]] | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208133805/http://www.villagevoice.com/news/0027,schoofs,16189,1.html | archivedate=8 February 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/52730299.html?dids=52730299:52730299&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Apr+19%2C+2000&author=Barton+Gellman&pub=The+Washington+Post&edition=&startpage=A.01&desc=S.+African+President+Escalates+AIDS+Feud |title= South African president escalates AIDS feud |first= B |last= Gellman |newspaper= [[Washington Post]] |date= 19 April 2000 |accessdate= 26 February 2007 |subscription=yes}}</ref>
AIDS scientists and activists were dismayed at the president's behavior and responded with the [[Durban Declaration]], a document affirming that HIV causes AIDS, signed by over 5,000 scientists and physicians.<ref name=durbandec/><ref name=Controversy/>
====Criticism of governmental response==== The former South African health minister [[Manto Tshabalala-Msimang]] also attracted heavy criticism, as she often promoted nutritional remedies such as garlic, lemons, [[beetroot]] and [[olive oil]], to people suffering from AIDS,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.health-e.org.za/news/article.php?uid=20031487 |title= Beetroot battle at world AIDS conference |first= A |last= Thom |website= Health-e.org.za |date= 21 August 2006 |accessdate= 9 March 2007 |deadurl= yes |archive-date= 23 August 2007 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070823213634/http://www.health-e.org.za/news/article.php?uid=20031487}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.mg.co.za/articlepage.aspx?area=/breaking_news/breaking_news__national/&articleid=280903 |title= 'Dr Beetroot' hits back at media over Aids exhibition |newspaper= Mail & Guardian |last= Blandy |first= Fran |date= 16 August 2006 |deadurl= yes |archive-date= 4 January 2007 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070104191247/http://www.mg.co.za/articlepage.aspx?area=%2Fbreaking_news%2Fbreaking_news__national%2F&articleid=280903 |accessdate= 20 September 2006 |df= dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.aegis.com/news/sapa/2005/sa050604.html |title= Manto again angers AIDS activists |work= AEGIS.com |agency= South African Press Association |accessdate= 20 September 2006 |deadurl= yes |archive-date= 30 September 2007 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930183013/http://www.aegis.com/news/sapa/2005/sa050604.html |date= 8 June 2005}}</ref> while emphasizing possible toxicities of antiretroviral drugs, which she has referred to as "poison".<ref name=asg>{{cite web|url=http://www.aidstruth.org/nattrass.pdf |title=AIDS, science and governance |first=N |last=Nattrass |work=aidstruth.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060623094834/http://www.aidstruth.org/nattrass.pdf |archivedate=23 June 2006 }}</ref> The [[South African Medical Association]] has accused Tshabalala-Msimang of "confusing a vulnerable public".<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.samedical.org/article.asp?ArticleID=1844 |title= SAMA calls for end to misrepresentation on treatment of AIDS |date= 29 August 2006 |publisher= [[South African Medical Association]] |accessdate= 12 March 2007 |deadurl= yes |archive-date= 10 August 2007 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070810234414/http://www.samedical.org/article.asp?ArticleID=1844}}</ref> In September 2006, a group of over 80 scientists and academics called for "the immediate removal of Dr. Tshabalala-Msimang as minister of health and for an end to the disastrous, pseudoscientific policies that have characterized the South African government's response to HIV/AIDS."<ref name=wpleonard>{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/06/AR2006090600586.html |title= Scientists rip S. African AIDS policies |first= T |last= Leonard |newspaper= Washington Post |date= 6 September 2006 |accessdate= 5 March 2007}}</ref> In December 2006, deputy health minister [[Nozizwe Madlala-Routledge]] described "denial at the very highest levels" over AIDS.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/main.jhtml?view=DETAILS&grid=&xml=/health/2006/12/11/wsa10.xml |title= African minister ends decade of denial over AIDS |newspaper= The Daily Telegraph |date= 12 November 2006 |accessdate= 5 March 2007 |location= London |first= S |last= Bevan |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070225015259/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/main.jhtml?view=DETAILS&grid=&xml=%2Fhealth%2F2006%2F12%2F11%2Fwsa10.xml |archivedate= 25 February 2007 |deadurl= no |df= dmy-all }}</ref>
Former South African president [[Thabo Mbeki]]'s government was widely criticized for delaying the rollout of programs to provide antiretroviral drugs to people with advanced HIV disease and to HIV-positive pregnant women. The national treatment program began only after the [[Treatment Action Campaign]] (TAC) brought a legal case against Government ministers, claiming they were responsible for the deaths of 600 HIV-positive people a day who could not access medication.<ref name=journaids/><ref>{{cite journal |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20061009025030/http://www.tac.org.za/Documents/MTCTCourtCase/Heywood.pdf |archive-date= 9 October 2006 |deadurl= yes |url= http://www.tac.org.za/Documents/MTCTCourtCase/Heywood.pdf |title= Current Developments: Preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission In South Africa: Background, strategies and outcomes of the Treatment Action Campaign case against the Minister Of Health |last= Heywood |first= M |date= 2003 |journal= South African Journal on Human Rights |via= tac.org.za |pages= 278–315}}</ref> South Africa was one of the last countries in the region to begin such a treatment program, and roll-out has been much slower than planned.<ref name=asg/>
At the [[XVI International AIDS Conference]], [[Stephen Lewis]], UN special envoy for AIDS in Africa, attacked Mbeki's government for its slow response to the AIDS epidemic and reliance on denialist claims: {{Quotation|It [South Africa] is the only country in Africa … whose government is still obtuse, dilatory and negligent about rolling out treatment… It is the only country in Africa whose government continues to promote theories more worthy of a lunatic fringe than of a concerned and compassionate state.<ref name=wpleonard/>}}
In 2002, Mbeki requested that HIV/AIDS denialists no longer use his name in their literature and stop signing documents with "Member of President Mbeki's AIDS Advisory Panel".<ref name=journaids/> This coincided with the South African government's statement accompanying its 2002 AIDS campaign, that "...in conducting this campaign, government's starting point is based on the premise that HIV causes AIDS".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.avert.org/aids-south-africa.htm |title= AIDS in South Africa: Treatment, transmission and the government |work= avert.org}}</ref> Nonetheless, Mbeki himself continued to promote and defend AIDS-denialist claims. His loyalists attacked former President [[Nelson Mandela]] in 2002 when Mandela questioned the government's AIDS policy, and Mbeki attacked [[Malegapuru William Makgoba]], one of South Africa's leading scientists, as a racist defender of "Western science" for opposing HIV/AIDS denialism.<ref name="nyt-dugger"/>
In early 2005, former South African President Nelson Mandela announced that his son had died of complications of AIDS. Mandela's public announcement was seen as both an effort to combat the stigma associated with AIDS, and as a "political statement designed to… force the President [Mbeki] out of his denial."<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1015842,00.html |title= No place for denial |first= S |last= Robinson |magazine= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date= 9 January 2005 |accessdate= 26 February 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/southafrica/story/0,13262,1384732,00.html?gusrc=rss |title= Mandela's eldest son dies of AIDS |first= T |last= Happold |newspaper= The Guardian |date= 6 January 2005 |accessdate= 9 March 2007}}</ref>
==== Post-Mbeki government in South Africa ==== In 2008, Mbeki was ousted from power and replaced as President of South Africa by [[Kgalema Motlanthe]]. On Motlanthe's first day in office, he removed [[Manto Tshabalala-Msimang]], the controversial health minister who had promoted AIDS-denialist claims and recommended garlic, beetroot, and lemon juice as treatments for AIDS. [[Barbara Hogan]], newly appointed as health minister, voiced shame at the Mbeki government's embrace of HIV/AIDS denialism and vowed a new course, stating: "The era of denialism is over completely in South Africa."<ref name="nyt-dugger"/>
==See also== * [[Discredited HIV/AIDS origins theories]] * [[Germ theory denialism]] * [[Misconceptions about HIV and AIDS]] * [[Vaccine controversies]]

==Further reading== * {{cite book |title= The Political Management of HIV and AIDS in South Africa: One Burden Too Many? |first= P |last= Fourie |publisher= [[Palgrave Macmillan]] |year= 2006 |isbn= 0230006671}} * {{Cite news |url= https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn17326-five-myths-about-hiv-and-aids.html |title= Five myths about HIV and AIDS |first= J |last= Steinberg |magazine= New Scientist |date=23 June 2009 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100102173656/http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn17326-five-myths-about-hiv-and-aids.html| archivedate= 2 January 2010 <!--DASHBot--> | deadurl= no}} * {{cite book |first= N |last= Nattrass |title= The AIDS Conspiracy: Science Fights Back |location= New York |publisher= Columbia University Press |date= 2012 |isbn= 9780231149129}}

{{Taxobox | name = Heavy-browed mouse opossum | image = | status = DD | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref name=iucn>{{IUCN2008|assessor=Diaz, M.|assessor2=Barquez, R.|last-assessor-amp=yes|year=2008|id=12812|title=Marmosa andersoni|downloaded=28 December 2008}} Database entry includes justification for why this species is data deficient</ref> | regnum = [[Animalia]] | phylum = [[Chordata]] | classis = [[Mammalia]] | infraclassis = [[Marsupialia]] | ordo = [[Didelphimorphia]] | familia = [[Didelphidae]] | genus = ''[[Marmosa]]'' | subgenus = ''[[Stegomarmosa]]'' | species = '''''M. andersoni''''' | binomial = ''Marmosa andersoni'' | binomial_authority = Pine, 1972 | synonyms = | range_map = Anderson's Mouse Opossum area.png | range_map_caption = Heavy-browed mouse opossum range }}
The '''heavy-browed mouse opossum''' (''Marmosa andersoni''), or '''Anderson's mouse opossum''', is a species of [[opossum]] in the family [[Didelphidae]].<ref name = MSW3>{{MSW3 Didelphimorphia | id = 10400071 | page = 8}}</ref> It is [[endemic]] to a restricted range in southern [[Peru]].<ref name=iucn/> This opossum inhabits forests; it is [[nocturnal]] and probably [[arboreal]].<ref name=iucn/>
==Description==
As only seven individuals have been observed, the species as a whole is limited in description. The dark grey fur on the upper parts is relatively long and tipped with reddish-brown, while the underside is paler. The hair on the cheeks and chin is cream colored, and prominent black rings surround the eyes.<ref name="ARKive">ARKive. Anderson’s mouse opossum (Marmosa andersoni). ARKive. Accessed 14 December 2012. Available from: http://www.arkive.org/andersons-mouse-opossum/marmosa-andersoni</ref><ref name="eol">Encyclopedia of Life. Marmosa Andersoni: Anderson’s Mouse Possum. Accessed 14 December 2012. Available from: http://eol.org/pages/290123/details</ref> Anderson's mouse opossum has large thin ears, providing acute hearing. The tail, which is longer than the head and body, is furry at the base, with bristles that become longer and more slender towards the tip.<ref name="ReferenceA">ARKive</ref><ref name="ReferenceB">eol</ref> Each foot has five digits and the big toe on the hindfoot is opposable, which, along with its prehensile tail, makes Anderson's mouse opossums well adapted for a life in the trees.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/>
==Habitat==
Little is known about the ecology of this species. It is nocturnal and may be arboreal. The diet of Marmosa consists largely of insects and fruits but also lizards, bird eggs and small rodents. The second locality where was captured this species is a mixture of forest and bamboo.<ref name="Solari">Solari, S. and Pine, R.H. (2008) Rediscovery and redescription of Marmosa (Stegomarmosa) andersoni Pine (Mammalia: Didelphimorphia: Didelphidae), an endemic Peruvian mouse opossum, with a reassessment of its affinities. Zootaxa, 1756: 49 - 61.</ref>
==Range==
Anderson's mouse opossum is known from only three localities, within a narrow strip along the base of the Andes, in Cusco, and southern Peru.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref name="ReferenceC">iucn</ref><ref>Solari</ref>
==Reproduction==
Anderson's mouse opossum is known only from one individual collected in 1954,<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/> and several more specimens caught in the late 1990s,<ref>Solari</ref> and thus very little is known about the biology of this incredibly rare animal. However, much can be deduced from studies of closely related species. It is likely to be nocturnal, and spend most of its time in trees.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> Like all marsupials, gestation is probably short, with females' giving birth to poorly developed young and most of the development taking place during lactation.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/> It is likely that reproduction is similar to that of ''Marmosa robinsoni'', which gives birth to 6 to 14 young after a gestation period of just 14 days. The tiny young, measuring only up to 12 millimeters, attach themselves to the mother's mammae where they may remain for around 30 days.<ref name="O'Connell">O'Connell, M.A. (1983) Marmosa robinsoni. Mammalian Species, 203: 1 - 6.</ref> Unlike many marsupials, female mouse opossums do not possess a pouch to protect the young as they develop. The young are so undeveloped their eyes do not open until 39 to 40 days. It is likely that the young are completely weaned after around 65 days, and they may have an incredibly short life span of only one year. Marmosa species build nests for shelter, or use abandoned bird nests, holes in trees, or banana stalks. These nest sites are unlikely to be permanent; rather, the opossum will use whatever site is available as the sun begins to rise. Like ''M. robinsoni'', it is likely that Anderson's mouse opossum is insectivorous, with fruit also playing an important role in the diet.<ref>O'Connell</ref>
==Conservation==
There are no major threats. In the one Western locality, there are natural gas fields in the Camisea region, which are being extracted; however, this is localized. Within the projected range, there is not a high rate of deforestation. In the vicinity of the eastern locality, there are threats including expanding coca crop.<ref name="ReferenceC"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.arkive.org/assam-macaque/marmosa-andersoni/ Photos at ARKive.]

'''Historical metrology''' is the science that is dealing with the fundamental units of measurement, systems of units formerly in use in various countries, and the development of monetary units throughout their history.
==Antiquarianism movement== The interest for historical metrology began by the early antiquarianism movement in Europe during 16th -17th centuries, when studies of the measurement systems in various ancient cultures became common, e.g. De Mensuris et ponderibus Romanis et Graecis, published in 1533 by [[Georgius Agricola]] (1494–1555). From the late 18th century and throughout the 19th century a plethora of books, with the aims to collate and clarify the relationships between different measurement systems and compile systems used in ancient cultures as well as in modern time, were published.
==Research efforts== Research efforts were later also used to investigate measurement system in certain cultures or countries. Here it is appropriate to mention Hultsch,<ref>Hultsch, Friedrich Otto. Metrologicorum scriptorium reliquiae, collegit, recensuit, partim nunc primum edidit Fridericus Hultsch. 2 volumes. 1864/1866. (Reprinted 1971 by B. G. Teubner, Stuttgart.) and Hultsch, Friedrich Otto. Griechische und Römische Metrologie. 2nd ed. Berlin: Weidmann, 1882.</ref> who published two monumental works, Griechische und römische Metrologie (1862) and Metrologicorum scriptorium reliquiae, collegit, recensuit, partim nunc primum edidit Fridericus Hultsch (1864/66).
Other works by scholars worth mentioning, is by Aravaca y Torrent<ref>Aravaca y Torrent, Antonio. Balanza métrica, ó sea Igualdad de las pesas y medidas legales de Castilla, las de las cuarenta y nueve provincias de España, sus posesiones de Ultramar, isla de Cuba, Puerto-Rico y Filipinas, y las de Francia, Inglaterra y Portugal: todas con el sistema métrico y viceversa ... Valencia: Impremia de José Domenech, 1867.</ref> (Spain, 1867), Balbin<ref>Balbin, Valentín (Departamento de ingenieros civiles). Sistema de medidas y pesas de la República Argentina. Buenos Aires: Tipografia de M. Biedma, 1881.</ref> (Argentina, 1881), Falkman<ref>Falkman, Ludvig B. Om mått och vigt i Sverige: historisk framställning – Den nyare tiden från och med år 1606 till och med år 1739. Stockholm, 1885.</ref> (Sweden, 1884/85), Ferrand<ref>Ferrand, Gabriel. 1920: Les poids, mesures et monnaies des mers du sud aux XVIe et XVIIe siécles. Journal asiatique (11th series) 16, 5-150 and 192-312.</ref> (Portuguese Territories of Indian Ocean, 1920), Hinz<ref>Hinz, Walther. Islamische Masse und Gewichte, umgerechnet ins metrische System. Leiden: E. J. Brill, 1955; Hinz, Walther. Islamische Währungen des 11. bis 19. Jahrhunderts. Umgerechnet in Gold. Ein Beitrag zur islamischen Wirtschaftsgeschichte. Wiesbaden: Otto Harrassowitz, 1991.</ref> (Islamic world, 1955), Wu <ref>Wu, Chengluo. Zhongguo dulianghengshi (xiudingben). ==Published reports== For some countries, principal divisions of executive governments have published reports that compile formerly used weights and measures. For example, this has been done for Bolivia, Great Britain, Costa Rica, Mexico, Portugal, Spain, Tanzania and the United States. In 1954, 1955,<ref>{{citation |ref={{harvid|UN|1955}} |title=World Weights and Measures: Handbook for Statisticians |url=https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001478405 |series=ST/STAT/SER. M/21, UN Publication No. 1955.XVII.2 |publisher=Statistical Office of the United Nations |location=New York |date=1955 }}.</ref> and 1966, the United Nation compiled reports that were aimed at giving an overview of the non-metric units then in use in different parts of the world.<ref>United Nations, Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East. Glossary of commodity terms including currencies, weights and measures used in certain countries of Asia and the Far East. New York: United Nations. Department of Economic Affairs, 1954; United Nations. Statistical Office of the United Nations in collaboration with the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United . World Weights and Measures. Handbook for Statisticians. New York, 1955. Provisional edition. Series: Statistical papers - United Nations. M, no. 21. (ST/STAT/SER.M/21 May 1955); United Nations. Department of Economic and Social Affairs. Statistical Office of the United Nations. World Weights and Measures. Handbook for Statisticians. Statistical Papers. New York. 1966. Series: M, no. 21 Revision 1. (ST/STAT/SER.M/21/rev.1).</ref> In 2018, the first of three volumes of the book "Encyclopaedia of Historical Metrology, Weights, and Measures", were published. The book addresses the myriad units of measurement that have arisen through the ages, from weights used by ancient cultures to the scientific units of the modern world.<ref>https://www.springer.com/gb/book/9783319575964</ref>
==Representatives== Among the representatives of historical metrology since the second half of the 20th century may be mentioned, among others [[Chengluo Wu]], [[Florian Huber]], [[Harald Witthöft]], [[István Bogdán]], [[Jan Gyllenbok]], [[Jean-Claude Hocquet]], [[Luís Seabra Lopes]], [[Pierre Charbonnier]], [[Richard Keir Pethick Pankhurst]], [[Rolf C A Rottländer]], [[Ronald Edward Zupko]] and [[Walther Hinz]].

{{italic title}} '''''Hot Dog''''' is a Saturday morning documentary series for children, seen on [[NBC]] from September 12, 1970 to September 4, 1971. Created by [[Frank Buxton]] and co-produced by Buxton and [[Lee Mendelson]], the program was notable for its hosts – [[Jo Anne Worley]], comedian [[Jonathan Winters]] and writer and actor [[Woody Allen]]. The pilot, televised on March 28, 1970, starred Worley, Allen and [[Tom Smothers]], who was replaced with Winters when the show became a series.
Based on Buxton's travels as a comedian (and later, as host of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] series, ''Discovery''), which took him on tours to various factories, ''Hot Dog'' explained, in a humorous manner, how we do things (such as snore) and how things were made (such as the eponymous hot dogs and their buns, plus condiments like mustard).
Seventy topics were covered during the course of this series, which lasted thirteen episodes and rerun the rest of the season. NBC won a Peabody award for the series in 1970.<ref>http://www.peabody.uga.edu/winners/winners_1970s.php</ref>
Some of the music in this series was performed by [[The Youngbloods]].
==Syndication and alternate versions== Reruns of ''Hot Dog'' were [[television syndication|syndicated]] during the 1977–1978 television season, at a time when Allen had firmly established himself as a motion picture star, director, and writer. Portions of ''Hot Dog'' were also seen on a local [[KNBC]] children's program in [[Los Angeles]], ''[[That's Cat]]'', which debuted in 1976.
In 1971 the Individual topic segments were sold to schools on 16mm film.
== List of Topics == (listed alphabetically) # "How does a frog jump?" # "How does a letter get through the mail?" # "How do they get toothpaste in the tube?" # "How do they make a baseball glove?" # "How do they make a hot dog roll?" # "How do they make a surfboard?" # "How do they make baseballs?" # “How do they make bicycles?” # "How do they make bowling balls?" # "How do they make bubblegum?" # "How do they make cartoons?" # "How do they make chocolate?" # "How do they make playing cards?" # "How do they make pennies?" # "How do they make plywood" # "How do they make spaghetti?" # "How do they make tennis shoes?" # "How do they make toothbrushes?" # "How do they make T-shirts?" # "How money is made" # "Is that really lead in a lead pencil?" # "What makes popcorn pop?" # "What's a compass?" # "Where does honey come from?" # "Where does Lumber come from?" # "Where do felt tip pens come from?" # "Who invented the hot dog?"

{{About|the 2016 book by Julian Guthrie about the Ansari X Prize|the makeup of spaceships|spacecraft}} {{italictitle}} {{Infobox book | italic title = How to Make a Spaceship | name = How to Make a Spaceship | image = How to Make a Spaceship book cover.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = Julian Guthrie | audio_read_by = Rob Shapiro | country = USA | language = English | subject = Spaceflight | genre = Non-fiction | publisher = Penguin Books | publisher2 = Random House | title_working = Beyond | pub_date = September 2016 | media_type = {{ubl|Hardcover|Softcover trade paperback|CD audiobook|Digital-file audiobook|Digital-file e-book}} | pages = 448 | awards = | isbn = 978-1101980491 | isbn_note = | oclc = 1011116852 | dewey = | congress = | wikisource = | notes = | website = [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCpblcn6YacX0p_O1lE6g2kA/ How to Make a Spaceship] }} '''How to Make a Spaceship'': A Band of Renegades, An Epic Race, And the Birth of Private Spaceflight''''' ({{ISBN|978-1594206726}}) is a bestselling award-winning 2016 non-fiction book by journalist [[Julian Guthrie]] about the origins of the [[X Prize Foundation]] and [[Peter Diamandis]], the first X Prize, the [[Ansari X Prize]] and [[Anousheh Ansari]], the entrants into that suborbital spaceflight competition, and the winning team, [[Mojave Aerospace Ventures]] of [[Vulcan Inc.]], [[Paul G. Allen]], [[Scaled Composites]], [[Burt Rutan]], and their platform of [[Scaled Composites Tier One|Tier One]] of [[SpaceShipOne]] and [[WhiteKnightOne]].<ref name=318656-9781101980491/><ref name=NYT-2016-11-13/><ref name=Guthrie-book/><ref name=Time-2016-09-20> {{cite magazine |url= http://time.com/4461689/how-to-make-a-spaceship/ |title= How Charles Lindbergh Inspired Private Spaceflight |author= Julian Guthrie |date= 20 September 2016 |publisher= Time Magazine }} </ref><ref name=NYJB-HTMASS/>
==Synopsis== The book is an overview of what lead to the creation of the X Prize, and the running of that first X Prize. Profiles of all the major players in the X Prize saga are included in the book. It chronologically starts with the influences that weighed upon Peter Diamandis, and his progression into the space industry. It also covers the process to get funding, rejections, and the arrival of the Ansaris, becoming title sponsors. The book surveys several of the teams that entered into the competition to win the Ansari X Prize. The team that is focused on most is that which won the X Prize in 2004, the one headed by Paul Allen and Burt Rutan, of SpaceShipOne. The book ends with an epilogue about [[Richard Branson]]'s [[Virgin Galactic]] scooping up the SpaceShipOne technology, and the spaceplane itself ending up in the [[Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum]]. The book includes a preface by Richard Branson, and an afterword by [[Stephen Hawking]].<ref name=TSR-2016-10-03> {{cite magazine |url= http://www.thespacereview.com/article/3071/1 |title= Review: How to Make a Spaceship |author= Jeff Foust |date= 3 October 2016 |publisher= The Space Review }} </ref><ref name=NYJB-HTMASS> {{Cite web |url= https://www.nyjournalofbooks.com/book-review/how-make-spaceship |title= How to Make a Spaceship: A Band of Renegades, an Epic Race, and the Birth of Private Spaceflight |author= Robert Schaefer |publisher= New York Journal of Books }} </ref><ref name=IAPR-2017-09-06> {{cite episode |url= http://iowapublicradio.org/post/how-make-spaceship |network= Iowa Public Radio |series= IPR |title= How to Make a Spaceship |author= Ben Kieffer; Katherine Perkins; |date= 6 September 2017 }} </ref><ref name=DW-2016-12-08> {{cite news |url= http://www.dw.com/en/how-to-make-a-spaceship-and-get-off-planet-with-renegades-and-college-dropouts/a-36690087 |title= How to make a spaceship and get 'off planet' with renegades and college-dropouts |author= Zulfikar Abbany |date= 8 December 2016 |publisher= Deutsche Welle }}</ref><ref name=WashPost-2016-09-19> {{cite newspaper |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/innovations/wp/2016/09/19/the-renegade-whose-dream-started-the-latest-space-race/?noredirect=on |title= The renegade whose dream started the latest space race |author= Vivek Wadhwa |date= 19 September 2016 |publisher= Washington Post }} </ref><ref name=SFGATE-2016-10-06> {{cite news |url= https://www.sfgate.com/books/article/How-to-Make-a-Spaceship-by-Julian-Guthrie-9882317.php |title= ‘How to Make a Spaceship,’ by Julian Guthrie |author= Tom Zoellner |date= 6 October 2016 |publisher= SFGate }} </ref>
==Publication== The book was originally entitled "''Beyond: Peter Diamandis and the Adventure of Space''", when it was sold preemptively to [[Penguin Books]] in 2014.<ref name=THR-2014-10-07> {{cite news |url= https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/xprize-space-race-story-gets-738773 |title= XPrize Space Race Story Gets Book Deal (Exclusive) |date= 7 October 2014 |author= Andy Lewis |publisher= The Hollywood Reporter }} </ref> "How to Make a Spaceship" was released in September 2016, in trade paperback, hardcover, audio book and e-book formats.<ref name=318656-9781101980491> {{cite web |publisher= Penguin Books Random House |url= https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/318656/how-to-make-a-spaceship-by-julian-guthrie/9781101980491/ |title= How to Make a Spaceship |year= 2016 }} </ref> The work was a finalist for a PEN Award, the [[PEN/E. O. Wilson Literary Science Writing Award|2017 PEN/E.O. Wilson Literary Science Writing Award]].<ref name=Deadline-2017-07-25/><ref name=PEN-Wilson-2017> {{cite web |url= https://pen.org/2017-pene-o-wilson-literary-science-writing-award/ |title= 2017 PEN/E. O. WILSON LITERARY SCIENCE WRITING AWARD |year= 2017 |publisher= PEN America }} </ref><ref name=EOWF-2017-01-20> {{cite web |url= https://eowilsonfoundation.org/2017-pene-o-wilson-literary-science-writing-award-finalists-announced/ |title= 2017 PEN/E.O. Wilson Literary Science Writing Award Finalists Announced |date= 20 January 2017 |publisher= E.O. Wilson Foundation }} </ref> The publication won the [[Eugene M. Emme Astronautical Literature Award|2016 Eugene E. Emme Award for Astronautical Literature]] in September 2017.<ref name=AAS-2017-09-08> {{cite web |url= http://astronautical.org/dev/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Emme_2016_PressRelease_Guthrie.pdf |title= Julian Guthrie Announced as Recipient of American Astronautical Society Emme Award |date= 8 September 2017 |author= Diane L. Thompson |publisher= American Astronautical Society (AAS) }} </ref><ref name=AAS-2017-09-14> {{cite web |url= http://astronautical.org/2017/09/14/emme-and-ordway-award-winners-announced/ |title= Emme and Ordway Award Winners Announced |author= Jim Way |date= 14 September 2017 |publisher= American Astronautical Society (AAS) }} </ref> It became a New York Times listed bestseller.<ref name=NYT-2016-11-13> {{cite newspaper |url= https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/2016/11/13/science/ |title= Science - Best Sellers - November 2016 |date= 13 November 2016 |publisher= New York Times }} </ref> The book has appeared on several "Best Of" book lists.<ref name=Deadline-2017-07-25> {{cite news |url= http://deadline.com/2017/07/alpha-girls-silicon-valley-female-hotshots-julian-guthrie-welle-entertainment-1202135781/ |title= Julian Guthrie Book ‘Alpha Girls’ Gets Scooped Up By Welle Entertainment After Bidding War |publisher= Deadline.com |author= Anita Busch |date= 25 July 2017 }} </ref> Several parties have expressed interest in obtaining the filming rights to the book.<ref name=2016-09-16> {{Cite episode |url= https://www.wired.com/2016/09/geeks-guide-x-prize-movie/ |title= Come on Hollywood, Give Us an X Prize Movie Already |number= 221 |series= Geek’s Guide to the Galaxy |publisher= Wired Magazine |date= 16 September 2016 }} </ref>
==Reception== Gregg Easterbrook's review in The Wall Street Journal said of the book that “'How to Make a Spaceship' offers a rousing anthem to the urge to explore."<ref name=Easterbrook-Review> {{Cite news |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-to-make-a-spaceship-takes-on-the-birth-of-the-second-space-age-1474058041 |title= ‘How to Make a Spaceship’ Takes on the Birth of the Second Space Age |author= Gregg Easterbrook |publisher= The Wall Street Journal |date= 16 September 2016 |work= Gregg Easterbrook review }} </ref>

[[File:Hyperchromicity.svg|thumb|right|250px|Nucleic acid melting curve showing hyperchromicity as a function of temperature]] '''Hyperchromicity''' is the increase of [[absorbance]] (''optical density'') of a material. The most famous example is the hyperchromicity of [[DNA]] that occurs when the DNA duplex is denatured.<ref>[https://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.jchemed.6b00095?journalCode=jceda8]</ref> The [[UV]] absorption is increased when the two single [[DNA]] strands are being separated, either by heat or by addition of denaturant or by increasing the [[pH]] level. The opposite, a decrease of absorbance is called '''hypochromicity'''.
==Hyperchromicity in DNA denaturation== Heat denaturation of DNA, also called [[DNA melting | melting]], causes the double helix structure to unwind to form single stranded DNA. When DNA in solution is heated above its melting temperature (usually more than 80 °C), the double-stranded DNA unwinds to form single-stranded DNA. The bases become unstacked and can thus absorb more light. In their native state, the bases of DNA absorb light in the 260-nm wavelength region. When the bases become unstacked, the wavelength of maximum absorbance does not change, but the amount absorbed increases by 37%. A double stranded DNA strand dissociating to two single strands produces a sharp cooperative transition.
Hyperchromicity can be used to track the condition of DNA as temperature changes. The transition/melting temperature (T<sub>m</sub>) is the temperature where the absorbance of UV light is 50% between the maximum and minimum, i.e. where 50% of the DNA is denatured.a ten fold increase of monovalent cation concentration increases the temperature by 16.6 degree C
The '''hyperchromic effect''' is the striking increase in absorbance of DNA upon denaturation. The two strands of DNA are bound together mainly by the stacking interactions, hydrogen bonds and [[hydrophobic effect]] between the complementary bases. The hydrogen bond limits the resonance of the aromatic ring so the absorbance of the sample is limited as well. When the DNA double helix is treated with denatured agents, the interaction force holding the double helical structure is disrupted. The double helix then separates into two single strands which are in the random coiled conformation. At this time, the base-base interaction will be reduced, increasing the [[UV]] absorbance of DNA solution because many bases are in free form and do not form hydrogen bonds with complementary bases. As a result, the absorbance for single-stranded DNA will be 37% higher than that for double stranded DNA at the same concentration.
==References== <references /> *[http://www.bx.psu.edu/~ross/ Laboratory of Ross Hardison], Article *[http://www.bx.psu.edu/~ross/workmg/Struc_Nucleic_Acids_Chpt2.htm Structures of Nucleic Acids] * Campbell, Mary K. & Farrell, Shawn O. (2006). ''Biochemistry''. Thomson Brooks/Cole.
